_prev_prog_2.Description: Information contained herein is relative to the cyclohexlamine storage and transfer facilities
Information contained herein is relative to the acrylonitrile storage and transfer facilities

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) developed the Risk Management
Program (RMP) rule (40 CFR 68)to assist facilities in preventing accidental releases of 
highly toxic or flammable chemicals.  The RMP established three levels of requirements 
for the program.  Programs 1 and 2 are for facilities that pose less risk to the 
environment and therefore have reduced compliance requirements.  Program 1 is designed 
for "no impact" facilities and has the fewest requirements, while Program 3 is the most
stringent of the three levels.

The program level for each facility is determined by:

       Use of regulated substances in threshold quantity
       Impact of an off-site public receptor (e.g., residence, school, park)
       North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) code
       Five-year accident history
       OHSA PSM (29 CFR 1910.119) applicability. 

This facility is regulated under Program 2 requirements under 40 CFR 68.10 because:

       It handles acrylonitrile and cyclohexylamine in excess of the threshold quantities
       A release from this facility could impact an offsite public Receptor
       (residence)
       It does not operate under a NAICS code specified in the rule
       It is not subject to OSHA PSM because PSM does not apply to flammable 
       liquids stored in atmospheric tanks which are kept below their normal 
       boiling point without benefit of chilling or refrigeration 
       [29 CFR 1926.64(a)(1)(ii)(B)].).

40 CFR Part 68 Subpart G applies to an owner or operator of a stationary source that has
more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance in a process, as determined under
40 CFR 68.115.  Stolthaven New Orleans, LLC (Stolthaven New Orleans) is a bulk chemical 
storage and transfer facility that handles more than the threshold quantities of both 
acrylonitrile (20,000 pounds) and cyclohexylamine (15,000 pounds).

Stolthaven New Orleans, LLC is committed to operating in a safe and compliant

manner. 
Employees involved in operating the acrylonitrile and cyclohexylamine handling facilities are 
trained to identify and understand the hazards posed during the storage and transfer 
process.  Process safety and emergency response materials are kept on site and periodically 
reviewed.  Training includes the review of information pertaining to the hazards of acrylonitrile
and cyclohexylamine, process technology, process equipment, and emergency response procedures.

One stationary source is the Stolthaven New Orleans acrylonitrile storage tank and related 
appurtenances.  The largest acrylonitrile process group (e.g., largest storage tank or 
group of interconnected tanks) has a storage capacity of 3,360,000 gallons (22,725,360 
pounds).  The total acrylonitrile stationary storage capacity is 22,725,360 pounds, which 
is stored in a single tank.

The second stationary source is the cyclohexylamine transfer and loading facility and related
appurtenances.  The largest cyclohexylamine process group includes an individual rail tankcar of
cyclohexylamine having a maximum storage capacity of 25,000 gallons (171,175 pounds).

The facility is required to complete one worst-case release scenario per hazardous substance
handled [68.165(a)(2)] to determine program applicability.  Stolthaven has chosen to use 
DEGADIS+ to determine offsite impacts because both acrylonitrile and cyclohexylamine vapors are 
heavier than air.

For this facility, a worst-case release of acrylonitrile would occur in the event that the 
largest (3,360,000-gallon) storage tank would rupture and the entire contents would be released to 
the atmosphere through evaporation.  This spill was modeled as continuous release because 
it would require more than 60 minutes to evaporate the contents of the tank.  In the case 
of acrylonitrile, the evaporation would take more than 68 hours.  The worst-case scenario 
requires a ground-level release height (0 feet).

The DEGADIS+ release model results indicate

a worst-case impact of 6.20 miles for an acrylonitrile
release from the facility.  The rule defines the toxic endpoint of acrylonitrile to be 0.076 mg/L.  
The affected population within a 6.20-mile radius of the facility is 111,587 based on the 1990 US 
Census population density data.   

For this facility, a worst-case release of cyclohexylamine would occur in the event that the 
largest (25,000-gallon) single container would rupture and the entire contents would be released to 
the atmosphere through evaporation.  This spill was modeled as continuous release because 
it would require more than 60 minutes to evaporate the contents of the tank.  In the case 
of cyclohexylamine, the evaporation would take more than 40 hours.  The worst-case scenario 
requires a ground-level release height (0 feet).

The DEGADIS+ release model results indicate a worst-case impact of 0.40 miles for a cyclohexylamine
release from the facility.  The rule defines the toxic endpoint of cyclohexylamine to be .16 mg/L.  
The affected population within a 0.40-mile radius of the facility is 20 based on the 1990 US 
Census population density data.

The facility is required to complete one alternate release scenario per regulated chemical 
per 40 CFR Part 68.165(a)(2).  The alternative release scenario considered is in accordance 
with the guidelines provided in 40 CFR 68.22 and 68.28.

The alternative scenarios for both acrylonitrile and cyclohexylamine chosen for this facility 
involve releases due to spills occuring during rail tankcar transfer operations.  While these 
scenarios are still unlikely because the operators are continuosly present during transfer 
operations, they are more likely than the worst-case scenarios required by 40 CFR 68.28(b)(i).  
Because personnel are always present at the facility during transfer, Stolthaven personnel can 
respond within 5 minutes.  The release rates were calculated as continuous evaporation from an 89 
gallon spill.  

The DAGADIS+ release model

indicates an alternative release scenario impact of 0.62 miles for
acrylonitrile and 0.26 miles for cyclohexylamine for the facility.  The affected population within 
a 0.62-mile radius of the facility is 100 for acrylonitrile and within a 0.20 mile radius is 10 
for cyclohexylamine based on the 1990 US Census population density data.

The facility maintains written process safety information to enable employees involved in 
handling both acrylonitrile and cyclohexylamine to identify and understand the hazards posed by 
these processes.  

Written training information includes the physical properties of acrylonitrile and cyclohexylamine, 
the health risks associated with chemical exposures, and material safety data sheets.  In addition, 
the facility has conducted and/or implemented the following:
          
             hazards review
             standard operating procedures
             training program
             maintenance program
             compliance audits
             incident investigation     

Stolthaven New Orleans, LLC has had no recordable accidents within the past five years. 
         
Recommendations for safety improvements were identified in the hazard review which was 
completed on May 7, 2003.  Recommendations were identified for two categories: Emergency
Response Procedures, and Training.  Safety improvements will be investigated concerning 
their impacts on other systems and/or procedures prior to implementation.  Additional 
recommendations may be made upon review of any accidents and/or when the hazard review 
is updated every five years.
